reviewText: I rarely watch documentaries about fans of a particular motion picture or motion picture genre. I don't consider myself as a Trekkie or a Star Wars fanatic, but after watching Firefly and Serenity I wanted to know more. I wanted to see more of what the fuss was about. I now consider myself a Browncoat.Done the Impossible: The Fans Tale of Firefly and Serenity is a unique feature. It was made by and stars the fans of Joss Whedon's franchise Firefly. More than a fan produced film it is a record of the grass roots activism of a small but growing group of fans who would not let the show they loved die and their work influenced Universal Pictures to turn their love into the motion picture Serenity.The film is hosted by Adam Baldwin and it follows the fans from Con to Con from screening to screening. It exhibits such joy that the viewer cannot help but be moved.The disc is one of the most jam packed single disc editions that I have ever seen. Broken into two parts: the DVD and the DVD-Rom there are almost 15 hours of material. The DVD includes an interactive timeline of the show, trivia games, charity spots, music videos, and five easter eggs. The DVD-Rom portion includes a completely interactive viewing experience that includes transcripts, extended interviews and biographies. All this material is fully searchable and is a lot of fun.If you are a fan of Firefly and Serenity do yourself a favor and seek this one out. It's worth it.
summary: We Have Done the Impossible and that Makes Us Mighty

reviewText: For anyone who's a fan of Firefly, or its big screen offspring, "Serenity", THIS DVD IS REQUIRED VIEWING!  In short, it's the story of the Browncoat fan movement, how it started, who these crazy people are, and how they made a not insignificant piece of Hollywood history.  Hosted by Adam Baldwin, this is the movie "Trekkies" wishes it was.I won't go into detail; half the fun is seeing everything for the first time, without any prior warning.Bottom line:  BUY THIS DVD!
summary: We Have Done The Impossible, And That Makes Us Mighty
Title: N/A

reviewText: Have to admit, I had never heard of Firefly before, although I do recall catching maybe the last 15 minutes or so of the very last episode when it was still running on the air.  Thought it was a cool premise, but never thought of it again until I saw the trailer for Serenity.  At that point, I thought there must of something about this show that I was missing. To make a long story short, I'm a fan now.This DVD is quite an accomplishment.  It's almost completely fan driven and to have a following this strong to develop (and complete)a project like this is absolutely amazing. If you're a fan yourself, you owe it to yourself to view this labor of love by folks who are probably just like you.  We may never see these great characters on the screen again, but like all loved ones from our past, we have this family album as a tribute to them.
Title: N/A

reviewText: As a huge Firefly fan I really loved this. This isn't just a documentary about the making and cancellation of a tv series and movie, it's also a tribute to the fans who made it possible. There are a lot of personal moments where fans speak about what Firefly means to them, especially fans who wrote letters etc to try to get it back on the air and have a movie made. There are lots of clips from cons and such with fans dressed up as characters from the show, which I thought was very sweet. Not many actors, directors, etc give a crap about the fans they inspire or what films and tv mean to the people who wait months or years for certain projects. It's really rare to see something like this. I think Firefly is going to have cult status for generations thanks to the fans.
Title: N/A

reviewText: There was a time when lots of people from all walks of life came together over a short lived TV series. Their common question was, "The show was so good they cancelled it?" It still resonates. I don't know anyone who doesn't like Firefly.When I show the series to someone today, they wonder aloud, 'why was it cancelled?'We got top notch entertainment for three months and made friends for life with strangers we see only at conventions. The point of this documentary is that people can come together over a common interest.As fans of a TV show that lasted only 13 episodes, we proved that there was an audience for it and that the network was WRONG for killing it. The fans are the reason the movie "Serenity" was made.Yes. We did the impossible. And that makes us mighty.Years later, most of the cast have their own TV shows, the writers are still creating and Joss Whedon is the director of one of the biggest movies of all time.So, maybe the fans knew what they were talking about.This is a time capsule.Fans in this film are still fans today.Whedon and crew made an impact on many lives with their message of family and independence."When you can't run, you crawl. And when you can't crawl....."You watch Firefly and it carries you away.There are many extras on this DVD.Interviews with fans and the stars that made them fans.It is sad at times. But, ten years later, we're still flying.
summary: A document that says "We were here!!"
Title: N/A

reviewText: There is a lot to enjoy on this DVD. The absence of Sean Maher, Summer Glau, and Gina Torres from the interviews was missed, but reports are they were unavailable due to scheduling conflicts, not from a desire to participate. Firefly, like other huge shows, has become part of our cultural heritage, and fans of other big SF shows like Star Wars and Star Trek have embraced this single-season series for truly well-crafted show it was. Fans are interviewed, conventions are visited, cast members interacting with fans and on one-on-one follow ups. It also documents the fan momentum to have the film, Serenity produced.Narrated by Jewel Staite and Adam Baldwin.  If you love the series, this is an enjoyable afternoon.

reviewText: I knew nothing about "Firefly" until my wife bought me the DVD set. She knew little of it other than she heard it was good and thought I'd like it. She was right in spades.Here's the scoop. This documentary takes you through the inception of the series through the viewer anticipation, Fox screwing it up big time, Fox cancelling it and the fans working their butts off to keep it alive. Then it delves into the fans' final triumph.I did learn some things about "Firefly" over the years. Particularly Fox's showing the episodes out of sequence. I thought this was odd. Were they TRYING to fail?! But I had no idea how strongly the fans felt about the cancellation and all that went on behind the scenes involving the efforts of them trying to get the show back. You get to hear from Joss Whedon, the actors, crew, editors and most everybody involved in the production along with their experience working on it and the subsequent, overwhelming outpouring of love, support and effort to keep it all going.I was dumbstruck. At one end it all sounds a little "Star Trek" silly. After all, it is only a TV show. But then I got to realize that it was also a vision. Who of us doesn't feel put out because of government intrusion? Every time you pay extra for something you feel should already be covered by your taxes and maybe once was. And the government keeps stacking it on so you want to board the ship with Malcolm Reynolds, one of the coolest characters ever, and head off where you won't be bothered?Watching these fans being interviewed really effected me. There seem like some of the greatest people ever. I wanted to be with them. Drink with them. Talk with them and play music with them. I've come to realize in my waning years that people can get along just fine with one another. It's government that drives rifts between us and screws things up. Seeing this documentary only strengthened that opinion for me.See it. You'll love it.

reviewText: I first heard about this at ComicCon, and I'm so glad I went straight here and bought it. If you are a "Firefly/Serenity" fan, it'll make you laugh and cry, sometimes at the same time - just like the show. Like many others, I didn't even become a fan until "Firefly" had left the air, so I was spared the agony of its cancellation, but I can share the pain watching these Browncoats relate how it hit them and be inspired by their determination to "do the impossible" and keep the show flying. Watch this, and you find yourself loving the fans, loving the actors, loving the crew, and above all, loving Joss Whedon for everything he brings to his 'verse. And now that I'm one of those still begging those who haven't seen "Firefly" to just go ahead and BUY the DVDs - don't bother renting... who's given it for Christmas and birthdays, and who still hopes for more....  Well, I watched this and laughed and cried and sang along and really loved every minute of it.

reviewText: This fan documentary was much, much better than I expected.I bought another documentary one once called Star Wait about Star Wars fans waiting in line for one of the prequels (Clones, I think). That was the worst DVD I have ever bought. It simply showed the Star Wars fans that most Star Wars fans are afraid will be seen in public and stigmatize them to the rest of the world. Just a bunch of people cussing who needed to grow up.Done The Impossible couldn't be more the opposite of Star Wait. It was very professionally done by people who loved Firefly. People who loved the show so much that they wanted to share it with those who haven't seen Firefly or Serenity.It was great to see some of the actors get in on the action and help out. That gave the video much more credibility than it would have had otherwise. We were shown actors who really loved what they were doing and wholeheartedly appreciated the fans for their support. Most actors wouldn't have stooped so low as to thank their audience.I am a Firefly fan. I am a Serenity fan. I became a fan too late to get in on the guerrilla marketing and writing campaigns. But if you are any kind of fan at all, you should buy this DVD. Anything to let stupid TV networks know that their customers are much more intelligent and have higher entertainment standards than they give us credit for....

reviewText: This documentary no doubt has new life on Netflix, where I recently found it. I usually like documentaries about obsessive fans and love Firefly but so...many...interviews. The whole film is seriously almost nothing but interviews. They even talked about people's fan projects but didn't show them besides songs.This is fine if you want to see the passion surrounding that moment of resurrection as the movie emerged in the mid-2000s. But that moment has passed and there's little relevance now to listening to people say how much they love the show without delving into many insights beyond that.

reviewText: This fan made DVD is awesome! Packed with lots of Firefly/Serenity goodness. No self-respecting Browncoat would be without this DVD. Lots of interviews with the cast and producers of Firefly/Serenity. Footage at different CON events plus this DVD is also a DVD-ROM for your computer, which packs additional footage and information from the verse. Jayne (Adam Baldwin) does the intros. and Kaylee (Jewel Staite) narrates different parts of the DVD. It makes a nice addition next to my Firefly boxset and Serenity DVD plus it helps support the Firefly/Serenity verse. I love Firefly! Please Joss, bring back Firefly!

reviewText: Excellently written and edited documentary.  Professional quality video and audio all the way through.  Moved along swiftly with chapters starting with clever and appropriate series quotes in white print on full black screen.  For example, Jayne's "Time for some thrilling heroics". Almost no duplication of special features from the Firefly and Serenity DVD to the best of my recollection.  Adam Baldwin was surprisingly easy to believe as a serious host even though his character in the movie is very different. I had to laugh when he says that some "fan fiction is kind of creepy".  Could he mean some of the Jayne/Mal or Jayne/Simon "slash" fiction out there?  I am also wondering why "Simon" and "River" didn't appear more.The DVD-ROM special features require Apple Quicktime. That's a shame, because everytime I've installed quicktime, I've regretted it when I tried to remove it.  It's like a boot sector virus and won't go fully away. I don't install it anymore regardless of the temptation. Why not provide a Windows solution?[Added 14Apr07:  I withdraw this objection as commenters note that Qtime is freely available on both Macs and Windows platforms so is a valid choice.  Also, for those who do not like Apple's Qtime, commenters point out a great alternative, QuickTimeAlt.]I'm not really a "browncoat" as the Serenity and Firefly fans call themselves, but do like the series and movie.  I really enjoyed the documentary since it showed the cast and crew "off-screen" and you got the feeling that this team put their hearts and souls into the series and the movie.  Come to think of it, maybe I am a browncoat, because I found myself totally agreeing with the end credits song, "I want my trilogy".
summary: Excellent Documentary about a Fan Family
Title: N/A

reviewText: First, I have a confession to make. Unlike many "Firefly" fans, I had never even heard of Joss Whedon when the show premiered on Fox in the Fall of 2002. I was not a member of the existing "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" and "Angel" fan base that anxiously awaited Whedon's latest offering--I had never seen either show. I did enjoy "Firefly" for the brief time that it aired (although I missed a few episodes), but I didn't really appreciate it until it was too late. I didn't get hooked until after I bought the complete series DVD set and saw "Serenity" on the big screen.I was a little hesitant about buying "Done the Impossible" at first, since I didn't think a "fan-produced" DVD could possibly have much to offer. Was I ever wrong! Every "Firefly" fan should have this. It may be a little too deep, esoteric or complicated for a casual viewer who just happened to catch a couple of episodes, or for someone who went to see "Serenity" for lack of something else to do. But if you've invested the time and energy to watch all of the episodes repeatedly, to learn the culture and terminology of the `Verse, to read the "Companion" books--then you need "Done the Impossible."The main feature of the DVD portion of the single-sided disk is a 79-minute documentary, with scene selections, that tells the story of the rise and fall of "Firefly." There's also an ultra-cool interactive audio/video timeline, a `Verse dictionary (in very small print that's a little hard to read on a normal-size television), a trivia game, commentaries, some music videos and other extras. Presented in a very clever multi-window format, the DVD/ROM portion has over six hours of  interviews, commentaries, music, factoids, biographies of cast, crew and fans, you name it. If it has to do with the birth, death and resurrection of the spaceship "Serenity" and her crew, you'll probably find it here. It's very interactive (as is the DVD). You won't just sit back and let this play, because the slick, professional interface practically forces you to click your way around the screen to see what you can find. It's a great way to present the material, but it does require some effort and concentration.Both the DVD and DVD/ROM have first-class production values that equal or exceed any other DVD I've ever seen. Even if you're not a certified, died-in-the-wool "Browncoat," you should consider buying "Done the Impossible." It tells a unique story that you won't find anywhere else. I recommend it highly.
Title: N/A
